messageBody:
I hope it's not too late for me to chime in on this. (Particularly since I'm
going to say the same thing as David and J.B. ;-)

You're thinking in terms that are too big.

Instead of:
public void test_First_UP_Button_Pressed() {
view.pressed(1, UP);
assertTrue(firstDoor.isOpen());
}

Just:
public void test_First_UP_Button_Pressed() {
assertEquals(0, model.activeButtonCount());
model.press(1, Direction.UP);
assertEquals(1, model.activeButtonCount());
assertTrue(model.isPressed(1, Direction.UP));
}

Note that this is focused on the model rather than the view.

There are probably lots of things that you expect to happen between pressing
the UP and the door opening. Where is the elevator right now? Is the
elevator on the first floor before the door opens?

When you test the view parts, you'll probably have a view.isButtonActive(1,
Direction.UP) since the button state should change once the elevator
arrives, right?

When I started trying to do test-first, it was very hard to think in tiny
steps, but that's the way that it works best. I still wouldn't say that my
Test-First behavior is a "habit" as I really have to think about it. Perhaps
one day it will feel natural, but I have to "undo" many, many years of
Code-First, Test-Later development.

-Rob
